author: Henry Jones
title: The world's most exhilarating drives revealed
text: Driving, you might think, is a simple business – an unremarkable procession from Start-point A to Destination B, with a few traffic lights and roundabouts sprinkled in the way. Not so. According to a new study, the perfect car journey requires just the right mixture of tight corners and long straight stretches – a combination which demands enough hard braking and wind-in-the-hair acceleration to test anybody's skills behind the steering wheel. • England's best scenic drives And the best roads for finding this heady cocktail of slow-fast-slow-fast are dotted all across the planet, according to a leading hire-car company. • The best scenic drives in Britain: in pictures Avis has compiled a list of the globe’s best highways for adventures in rapid deceleration and putting your foot to the floor – with scenic routes in countries as varied as Italy, South Africa, Romania, the United States, New Zealand and France all making the grade. • Scotland's best scenic drives The UK also features in the list in the form of Bealach na Ba – a twisting ribbon of tarmac which picks a hairpin-laden route through the Applecross peninsula in the Scottish Highlands. • Wales' best scenic drives Here is a treat for any traveller who takes their driving seriously – a phenomenon which manages the highest climb of any road in the UK, rising 2064ft (626 metres) from sea level to its loftiest point. In parts, it rachets its gradient to 20 per cent. Nonetheless, it offers plenty of scope for easy progress. According to the Avis study, 81 per cent of the pass can be ranked as straight road for cruising at the same speed, with the other 19 per cent of the journey split into sections that require acceleration (five per cent), braking (three per cent) and cornering (10 per cent). world's most exhilarating drives By contrast, the “Tail of the Dragon”, a portion of US Route 129 which snakes through the Great Smoky Mountains in the far west corner of North Carolina – where the state runs into Tennessee – makes far greater demands of the driving abilities of those who tackle it. Only 45 per cent of its camber can be considered prime terrain for cruising, with corners making up more than a third of the road (35 per cent). Sections for braking (seven per cent) and acceleration (13 per cent) complete the picture. This proliferation of swerves and curves makes the route a popular choice for bikers and weekend road-trippers. • The world's best drives Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel
